ranked_diseases.explanation: Patient presents with key features of BBS including postaxial polydactyly, nyctalopia, reduced visual acuity, and obesity. All three reference cases with similar phenotypes were diagnosed with BBS1. The visual disturbances (nyctalopia, reduced visual acuity, astigmatism) are consistent with the retinal dystrophy seen in BBS.

BBS2 presents with similar clinical features to BBS1 including polydactyly, retinal dystrophy, and obesity. The phenotypic overlap between different BBS subtypes makes this a strong differential diagnosis.
Another BBS subtype that can present with the same constellation of symptoms. BBS10 is one of the more common forms of BBS and should be considered in the differential.

Shares several features with the patient including obesity, visual impairment (cone-rod dystrophy causing nyctalopia and reduced visual acuity), and can have ptosis. However, lacks polydactyly which is a distinguishing feature.
Can present with obesity, visual problems including nyctalopia and reduced visual acuity due to chorioretinal dystrophy, and ptosis. However, polydactyly is not a typical feature.
Presents with postaxial polydactyly and can have some overlapping features with BBS. However, typically lacks the progressive retinal dystrophy and obesity seen in this patient.
